results.title: Africa dances
results.creator_credit: Ramakantha Sarma, Ben Park, George Movshon and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: Presents the performance given by Les Ballets Africains in the General Assembly Hall of the United Nations Headquarters on the anniversary of the adoption by the UN of the Human Rights declaration. The vivacity of this authentic dance group is complemented by accompanying instruments. With an introduction by H. E. M. Achkar Marof, ambassador from Guinea to the UN, translated by Alistair Cooke.

results.title: Africa awakens modern Nigeria
results.creator_credit: J. Michael Hagopian and Atlantis Productions
results.brief_description: Presents Nigeria, the most populated country in Africa progressing in the use of modern techniques and self-government. Stresses the influences of climate and geography on the economy, urbanization and education. Shows how the country has developed from a rich and ancient civilization, to becoming an independent nation.

results.title: Afghanistan: the land of crags and deserts
results.brief_description: This film, without narration, includes various aspects of life in Afghanistan. Shows mosques, markets, women in chaderi, camel caravan watering sheep in a desert area, the game of buzkashi a form of polo which uses a headless goat, and examples of weaving and dancing.

results.title: Aetna: a volcanic eruption on the island of Sicily
results.brief_description: Records, un-narrated, with only a descriptive jazz score, the basic stages of an eruption of Mount Aetna, on the east coast of Sicily. It gives a non-verbal picture of one of the most dramatic of natural events, and is also an indirect portrait of Aetna itself.

results.title: Aerial fencing
results.brief_description: With the opening up of new pastures in New Zealand many hundreds of miles of new fencing were required; aircraft which have been previously employed in distributing fertilizers, were used to drop fencing posts and wire. The materials were carried in racks under the wings of the planes and deposited in the areas required.

results.title: Aerial farming services in New Zealand
results.creator_credit: Alert Films and Soil Conservation and Rivers Control Council
results.brief_description: The use of aeroplanes in schemes for restoring eroded lands to former fertility by dropping fertilizers to improve pasture and poison to combat the rabbit menace. Shows Tiger Moth aircraft being fitted to spray chemical compounds; mechanical loading of fertilizer into planes; aircraft in flight and spraying from the air. Points out the saving in time and money that results from the use of aircraft.

results.title: Aerial attack on grass fires
results.brief_description: A trial demonstration was arranged at Orange, N.S.W., in which a Cessna plane carrying 75 gallons of water was used to find out what part light aircraft can play in fighting grass fires. Although the test was inconclusive it did show that a small plane would be of no use on a day of extreme fire danger.

results.title: Aeradio: the pilot's link to the ground
results.creator_credit: John Martin-Jones, Australian National Film Board and Department of the Interior
results.brief_description: An insight into the work of the Communications Officers - the men who keep a constant radio check on all aircraft in the air, maintaining voice or morse contact with the pilots, supplying information on weather conditions ahead, giving position, and acting, generally, as the pilot’s agent on the ground.
